Award.AwardTitle: Building Success: One Step at a Time

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project has two goals: 1) to increase the number of students who are
U.S. citizens or permanent residents and have a STEM major and 2) to increase the number of students who graduate or transfer to four-year institutions to complete their STEM baccalaureate degrees. To help achieve these goals strong emphasis is placed on academic excellence through activities offered to keep the students engaged and participating at a high level. These activities include research experiences, civic engagement, supplemental instruction, first-year experiences, cohort advising, faculty mentoring, STEM workshops and seminars. The broad array of disciplines represented by STEM faculty who can assist students as advisers, the variety of articulation agreements with four-year institutions, and the selection of business and university collaborations available to engage students in research and internships provide students with a broad intellectual base from which to draw.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Georgia State University Perimeter College (GSU PC) is a two-year, nonresidential, diverse multi campus institution in metropolitan Atlanta. The STEP grant major goals were to increase the number of U.S. citizens or permanent residents who enroll in all STEM fields and to increase the number of students who graduate and/or transfer to four-year institutions to complete their STEM baccalaureate degrees. During the grant period, substantial efforts focused on recruitment, persistence, academic standing and graduation/transfer rates. To strategically achieve program goals, high school visitation days (college course visits), participant support, STEM seminars, club fairs, college tours, industry visits, semester orientations, civic engagement, meet and greets, STEM week events, panel discussions, academic tutoring, research experience for undergraduates (REUs) and advisement (assigned faculty advisors), were designed to help students navigate and succeed in their STEM program pathway.

Over 500 pre-college students per year received information about the STEP grant and STEM initiatives at the college. As the project progressed, we experienced an increase in participation through advertising flyers, faculty recommendations, college recruiters and a STEP website.  Annually, through our recruitment tactics (club day and meet and greet activities), thirty new freshmen became program participants. However, we found the most effective mode of recruiting was to use participants already in the program as spokespersons to share how program activities encourage them to remain in STEM fields. Impactful stories from our alums and enrolled participants boosted the program reputation and became the most influential recruitment strategy. The grant allowed us to provide participant support and keep students on campus, to receive peer-tutoring and supplemental instruction in challenging (gateway) STEM courses.

Throughout the grant period, greater than 50% of the program participants received support (some of the students indicated that their goal was not to earn support but to take advantage of what the program has to offer).  Sixty-one percent persisted from one academic year to the next year, in the final year of the grant, all of the participants remained in good academic standing,  and 58% graduated and transferred to a four-year institution within two years.

The STEP grant allowed us to establish a fully funded Summer Bridge research model (SB I, SBII, and SBII) at Georgia State University Perimeter College that had a significant impact on the persistence of program participants. Summer Bridge I was a collaborative effort between Peach State LSAMP and STEP scholars. Summer Bridge I, an intensive three-week research exposure program at GSU PC, allowed students to master research techniques that made them competitive when applying for REUs and internships.  At the end of the program, there was a closing ceremony where students gave oral presentations on their findings and prepared research posters. Summer Bridge II (plus 8) was a combination of the three-week program with eight weeks of research at a four-year institution in the Atlanta area. Summer Bridge II research experience familiarized scholars with research teams composed of research faculty, postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students. Summer Bridge III allowed STEP scholars that participated in SB I and SB II to apply for domestic or international REUs, based on program requirements. Participants that remained at the college after SB III presented their scientific inquest at professional conferences. Exposure to research has increased the number of students applying for REUs at research institutions.

The STEM seminar series provided a platform for networking opportunities with faculty from transferring institutions and to provide REU exposure for scholars. The STEM seminar is being retained by the Science Department of Decatur campus.

Throughout the fall of 2012, supplemental instruction (SI) sessions for Chemistry 1211 (Principles of Chemistry) and Precalculus were held on  Tuesdays and Wednesdays.  Supplemental instruction sessions were taught by STEP student leaders in I hour sessions or 1.5 hour sessions. Students that participated in the sessions persisted and improved their academic performance in the courses, when compared to non SI sections. SI is being sustained by the college.

By creating a community of learners through peer tutoring and supplemental instruction in the Learning and Tutoring Center (LTC) and STEM resource centers, our students have developed a sense of belonging. Interaction with peers (buddy system) and faculty advisors was pivotal in keeping participants on track, because they had someone that understood their plight and held them accountable.

Annual surveys completed by program participants demonstrated significant gains in STEM engagement, identity, comfort with mathematics and science, encouragement and intent to persist.  A multiple regression analysis of response on open-ended questions on surveys and focus group interviews suggested that the STEP program positively impacted the motivation of participants to pursue STEM education by enhancing their sense of STEM identity and belonging by providing social support and encouragement. Furthermore, constructs indicated that program participants were more likely to complete their program of study and graduate/transfer to four-year institutions to pursue a STEM degree.
